title: Grenfell survivor says 'firefighters save my life' but she's 'terrified it'll happen again'
text:

Natasha Elcock was one of the many people living in Grenfell Tower who had been told to stay in her home when the blaze broke out in June 2017.

The brave mum's quick-thinking actions saved the lives of her family when she flooded her flat.

She kept her daughter on the wet floor and made sure her family stayed in the coldest room.

Firefighters eventually reached the stricken family at 3am and led them to safety after Natasha called for help more than 100 times.

Now chairman of Grenfell United, Natasha has insisted the firefighters that night saved her life.

(Image: Adam Sorenson)

She said: "I try not to think about the night of the 14 June 2017. It was the worst night of my life. I will never forget waiting for hours with my daughter to be rescued.

"I was one of the lucky ones and I will always remember that, I made it out. Many did not. "

Natasha has spoken out after firefighters were criticised in the Grenfell disaster inquiry's report, which has accused the government of "evading scrutiny".

The first part of the inquiry report into the June 2017 blaze, which killed 72 people, has been leaked. It focuses on the events of the night.

In it, inquiry chairman Sir Martin Moore-Bick criticised London Fire Brigade’s “stay put” policy, and said lives could have been saved if people had been evacuated earlier.

(Image: Getty)

Residents were told to remain in their flats for nearly two hours after the fire, which began in a fridge-freezer, broke out.

Sir Martin praised firefighters’ bravery, and said the “principal” reason the blaze spread so quickly was because the block’s flammable cladding “acted as a source of fuel”.

But he said many “institutional” failures meant the brigade’s preparation for such an incident was “gravely inadequate”.

And he censured LFB commissioner Dany Cotton’s “remarkable insensitivity” in saying she would not have changed anything about the night’s response.

The report also found mistakes made in responding to the Lakanal House high-rise fire, in Camberwell, South London, in 2009, which killed six, “were repeated”.

Natasha's main hope is that the mistake that led to the loss of so many lives are never repeated.

She said: "This report is for everyone who lost their lives and their families. We must learn what went wrong.

"We must expose the truth and make sure this never happens again. So many false things have been written about Grenfell. I hope this report will be the start of setting the record straight."

The mum has never blamed her neighbour, in whose flat the fire broke out.

She said: "Firstly, this report totally exonerates our neighbour on the 16th floor.

(Image: PA)

"The fridge started the fire. Our neighbour did everything he could to raise the alarm and protect his neighbours."

Natasha also wants to next part of the inquiry to focus on the building itself.

She said: "The next phase of the inquiry must put an end to the buck passing and fearlessly go after the people at these organisations who bear responsibility.

"The report does not blame junior firefighters for the fire as some people are claiming.

"My family was saved by firefighters that came up to the 11th floor. I owe them my life.

"The report focuses on the institutional and leadership failings at the top of the fire brigade.

(Image: PA)

"Many lives were lost, and families deserve for the findings Sir Martin Moore Bick gives to be taken seriously and not dismissed as unfair. His points are fair.

"He details that the leaders failed to learn lessons from a previous fire at Lakanal House.

"The leaders should have trained for evacuation and fire safety inspections at the tower should have been done properly."

But Natasha's greatest fear is that the tragedy will happen again if lessons aren't learned.

She said: "Tonight, hundreds of people are still going to bed in buildings with dangerous combustible materials on them.

"The report shows that a simple kitchen fire was all it took for this dangerous materials to catch fire and cause the devastation a Grenfell.

"We are terrified that this could happen again. The Government should have already got the cladding down and it is inexcusable that that is not the case.

" The Government need to see this as a national emergency and act now. This is a strong report. It is a fair report. And now change must come."
description: Natasha Elcock was one of the families who made it out of the tower block thanks to her quick-thinking actions and the firefighters who rescued her and her family
